mn33:0.2: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd
mn33:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn33:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the bhikkhus,
mn33:2.1: “Bhikkhus, a cowherd with eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
mn33:2.3: It’s when a cowherd doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:2.4: A cowherd with these eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
mn33:3.1: In the same way, a bhikkhu with eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
mn33:3.3: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to senior bhikkhus of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:4.1: And how does a bhikkhu not know form?
mn33:4.2: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t understand as it is that all form consists of the four great elements and form derived from the four great elements.
mn33:4.3: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t know form.
mn33:5.1: And how is a bhikkhu not skilled in characteristics?
mn33:5.2: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t understand that a fool is characterized by their actions, and a wise person is characterized by their actions.
mn33:5.3: That’s how a bhikkhu isn’t skilled in characteristics.
mn33:6.1: And how does a bhikkhu not pick out flies’ eggs?
mn33:6.2: It’s when a bhikkhu tolerates a sensual, averse, or cruel thought that has arisen. He tolerates bad, detrimental phenomena that have arisen. He doesn’t give them up,  dispel them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
mn33:6.3: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs.
mn33:7.1: And how does a bhikkhu not dress wounds?
mn33:7.2: Having seen a sight with the eye, he grasps at signs and features of it
mn33:7.3: on account of which—due to abiding with the eye faculty unrestrained—bad, detrimental phenomena of longing and upset would flow in on him. He doesn’t practice to restrain that; he doesn’t guard the eye faculty or bring about the restraint of the eye faculty.
mn33:7.4: Having heard a sound with the ear  …
mn33:7.5: Having smelled an odor with the nose …
mn33:7.6: Having tasted a flavor with the tongue …
mn33:7.7: Having touched a touch with the body …
mn33:7.8: Having cognized a phenomenon with the mental faculty, he grasps at the signs and features of it
mn33:7.9: on account of which—due to abiding with the mental faculty unrestrained—bad, detrimental phenomena of longing and upset would flow in on him. He doesn’t practice to restrain that; he doesn’t guard the mental faculty or bring about the restraint of the mental faculty.
mn33:7.10: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t dress wounds.
mn33:8.1: And how does a bhikkhu not spread smoke?
mn33:8.2: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t teach others the Dhamma in detail as he learned and memorized it.
mn33:8.3: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t spread smoke.
mn33:9.1: And how does a bhikkhu not know the ford?
mn33:9.2: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t from time to time go up to those bhikkhus who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic code, and the outlines—and ask them questions:
mn33:9.5: Those venerables don’t clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt in regard to the many doubtful matters.
mn33:9.6: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t know the ford.
mn33:10.1: And how does a bhikkhu not know satisfaction?
mn33:10.2: It’s when a bhikkhu, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, he doesn’t realize the Dhamma and its meaning, and doesn’t gain gladness connected with the Dhamma.
mn33:10.3: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t know satisfaction.
mn33:11.1: And how does a bhikkhu not know the trail?
mn33:11.2: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t understand the Noble Eightfold Path as it is.
mn33:11.3: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t know the trail.
mn33:12.1: And how is a bhikkhu not skilled in pastures?
mn33:12.2: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t understand the four establishments of recollection as they are.
mn33:12.3: That’s how a bhikkhu is not skilled in pastures.
mn33:13.1: And how does a bhikkhu milk dry?
mn33:13.2: It’s when a bhikkhu is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, and that bhikkhu doesn’t know moderation in accepting.
mn33:13.3: That’s how a bhikkhu milks dry.
mn33:14.1: And how does a bhikkhu not show extra respect to senior bhikkhus of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?
mn33:14.2: It’s when a bhikkhu’s bodily, verbal, and mental actions towards senior bhikkhus of long standing—long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha—are not friendly, whether in public or in private.
mn33:14.5: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t show extra respect to senior bhikkhus of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:14.6: A bhikkhu with these eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
mn33:15.1: A cowherd with eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
mn33:15.3: It’s when a cowherd knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, spreads smoke, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:15.4: A cowherd with these eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
mn33:16.1: In the same way, a bhikkhu with eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
mn33:16.3: It’s when a bhikkhu knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, spreads smoke, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to senior bhikkhus of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:17.1: And how does a bhikkhu know form?
mn33:17.2: It’s when a bhikkhu understands as it is that all form consists of the four great elements and form derived from the four great elements.
mn33:17.3: That’s how a bhikkhu knows form.
mn33:18.1: And how is a bhikkhu skilled in characteristics?
mn33:18.2: It’s when a bhikkhu understands that a fool is characterized by their actions, and a wise person is characterized by their actions.
mn33:18.3: That’s how a bhikkhu is skilled in characteristics.
mn33:19.1: And how does a bhikkhu pick out flies’ eggs?
mn33:19.2: It’s when a bhikkhu doesn’t tolerate a sensual, averse, or cruel thought that has arisen. He doesn’t tolerate any bad, detrimental phenomena that have arisen, but gives them up, dispels them, eliminates them, and obliterates them.
mn33:19.3: That’s how a bhikkhu picks out flies’ eggs.
mn33:20.1: And how does a bhikkhu dress wounds?
mn33:20.2: Having seen a sight with the eye, he doesn’t grasp at signs and features of it
mn33:20.3: on account of which—due to abiding with the eye faculty unrestrained—bad, detrimental phenomena of longing and upset would flow in on him. He practices to restrain that; he guards the eye faculty and brings about the restraint of the eye faculty.
mn33:20.4: Having heard a sound with the ear …
mn33:20.5: Having smelled an odor with the nose …
mn33:20.6: Having tasted a flavor with the tongue …
mn33:20.7: Having touched a touch with the body …
mn33:20.8: Having cognized a phenomenon with the mental faculty, he doesn’t grasp at signs and features of it
mn33:20.9: on account of which—due to abiding with the mental faculty unrestrained—bad, detrimental phenomena of longing and upset would flow in on him. He practices to restrain that; he guards the mental faculty and brings about the restraint of the mental faculty.
mn33:20.10: That’s how a bhikkhu dresses wounds.
mn33:21.1: And how does a bhikkhu spread smoke?
mn33:21.2: It’s when a bhikkhu teaches others the Dhamma in detail as he learned and memorized it.
mn33:21.3: That’s how a bhikkhu spreads smoke.
mn33:22.1: And how does a bhikkhu know the ford?
mn33:22.2: It’s when from time to time a bhikkhu goes up to those bhikkhus who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic code, and the outlines—and asks them questions:
mn33:22.5: Those venerables clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt in regard to the many doubtful matters.
mn33:22.6: That’s how a bhikkhu knows the ford.
mn33:23.1: And how does a bhikkhu know satisfaction?
mn33:23.2: It’s when a bhikkhu, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, realizes the Dhamma and its meaning, and gains gladness connected with the Dhamma.
mn33:23.3: That’s how a bhikkhu knows satisfaction.
mn33:24.1: And how does a bhikkhu know the trail?
mn33:24.2: It’s when a bhikkhu understand the Noble Eightfold Path as it is.
mn33:24.3: That’s how a bhikkhu knows the trail.
mn33:25.1: And how is a bhikkhu skilled in pastures?
mn33:25.2: It’s when a bhikkhu understands the four establishments of recollection as they are.
mn33:25.3: That’s how a bhikkhu is skilled in pastures.
mn33:26.1: And how does a bhikkhu not milk dry?
mn33:26.2: It’s when a bhikkhu is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick,
mn33:26.3: and that bhikkhu knows moderation in accepting.
mn33:26.4: That’s how a bhikkhu doesn’t milk dry.
mn33:27.1: And how does a bhikkhu show extra respect to senior bhikkhus of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?
mn33:27.2: It’s when a bhikkhu’s bodily, verbal, and mental actions towards senior bhikkhus of long standing—long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha—are friendly, whether in public or in private.
mn33:27.5: That’s how a bhikkhu shows extra respect to senior bhikkhus of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:27.6: A bhikkhu with these eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.”
mn33:27.7: That is what the Buddha said.
mn33:27.8: Pleased, the bhikkhus delighted in what the Buddha said.
